citation.article-title: Description of four novel psychrophilic, ionizing radiation-sensitive Deinococcus species from alpine environments.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Deinococcus radiomollis sp. nov. Callegan, da Costa and Rainey
Deinococcus radiomollis (ra.di′o.mol′lis. L. n. radius a ray; L. adj. mollis soft, susceptible; N.L. masc adj. radiomollis susceptible to radiation).
Forms rod-shaped cells 2.4–2.7 μm long and 1.2–1.3 μm wide.
Cells are non-motile; spores are not observed.
Colonies on 1/10-strength PCA medium are pink-pigmented.
Growth occurs between 5 and 25 °C but not at 2 or 30 °C.
The fatty acid profile is dominated by 16 : 1ω7c, 17 : 0 iso and 15 : 1ω6c.
Utilizes l-arabinose, cellobiose, galactose, d-glucose, fructose, mannose, l-rhamnose, sucrose, trehalose, xylose, glucosamine and glycerol.

The following substrates are not utilized: melibiose, lactose, raffinose, ribose, sorbose, acetate, citrate, glutamate, α-ketoglutarate, lactate, malate, aspartate, cysteine, alanine, asparagine, glutamine, glycine, lysine, methionine, ornithine and proline.
Starch, casein and gelatin are not degraded.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 63.2 mol%.
Sensitive to gamma and UV radiation and desiccation as compared with other species of the genus.
The type strain, PO-04-20-132T (=LMG 24019T=NRRL B-41950T), was isolated from an alpine soil at 5065 m on Pico de Orizaba, Mexico.
Strain PO-04-20-144 (=LMG 24018=NRRL B-41951) has been deposited as a reference strain of this species.
